item.title: The Logic of Adaptation
item.description:
Forming a robust conceptual framework in biology requires understanding levels of biological explanation, but perhaps most importantly, it requires understanding the evolutionary principles buttressing the discipline as a whole (Dobzhansky, 1973; Scott, 2010). Despite this, hundreds of studies indicate that students maintain tenacious misconceptions regarding such principles. To dissect these misconceptions further, we administered a pre-post assignment with open-ended reflective questions to explore (1) how students construct explanations about natural selection and adaptation across several levels of postsecondary study, and (2) the extent to which their explanations change as they experience continued formal instruction in biology.

Dobzhansky, T. (1973). Nothing in biology makes sense except in the light of evolution. The American Biology Teacher, 35(3), 125–129.

Mayr, E. (1961). Cause and effect in biology. Science, 134(3489), 1501–1506.

Scott, E. C. (2010). Dobzhansky was right: Let’s tell the students. Bioessays, 32(5), 372–374.
